Throughout his illustrious career, Richard Gere has established himself as a talented and versatile actor, earning the admiration of audiences worldwide.

Richard Tiffany Gere was born on August 31, 1949, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He is the second of five children to Homer George Gere, an insurance agent, and Doris Ann (née Tiffany), a homemaker.

Gere grew up in a Catholic family and was raised in Syracuse, New York. He began playing the piano at age 9 and later attended the Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan. He then enrolled at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, where he studied philosophy and drama.

After college, Gere moved to New York City to pursue an acting career. He began his career in the 1970s, landing small roles on stage and screen. His breakthrough came in 1978 with the film "Days of Heaven," directed by Terrence Malick.

Gere's subsequent films showcased his versatility and range, including "American Gigolo" (1980), "An Officer and a Gentleman" (1982), "Pretty Woman" (1990), and "Chicago" (2002). He received critical acclaim for his performances in "Chicago" and "Nights in Rodanthe" (2008), earning a Golden Globe nomination for the latter.

He has been a long-time supporter of the Tibetan people and has worked closely with the Dalai Lama. In 1999, he founded the Tibet House US, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting Tibetan culture and preserving Tibetan traditions.

Gere has been married three times: to actress Carey Lowell (2002-2016), actress Carrie Fisher (1975-1976), and model Sylvia Hiersche (1967-1971). He has one daughter, Homer James Jigme Gere, born in 2007.

With a career spanning over four decades, Richard Gere has established himself as a talented and dedicated actor, known for his captivating performances and commitment to social causes.
